displayed_text: Patient: Yep. Doctor: Vitamin B-twelve once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: four pills a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: You know. You have a drug, so it’s one pill each morning. Patient: Yep. For two weeks. Two weeks off, two weeks on. Doctor: You still on the Zoloda? Today? Patient: Yes. Doctor: per day any other medicine vitamins? Patient: Yes. Doctor: multivitamin steady today? Patient: two more pills; Optim- and two more pills

Healthcare Professional: As of right now, yes. Doctor: Ok, I gotta do something about that. Doctor: So I can't believe so many people are willing to come in the week of Thanksgiving, but ok. Patient: Yeah. (pause) Healthcare Professional: Alright, so I'll make a copy of these and then when you're done treatment you can--or while they're ordering the drug, if you want to go over and make your appointments-- Patient: Go see Y__? Healthcare Professional: Yep, she just has to sign these first. So… Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: They won't take them without her signature. Doctor: I’m just a - I’m just wondering, how long did we wait? We waited two weeks now? Healthcare Professional: It was two weeks from-- Doctor: Two weeks from his last uh, when he was last due?

Patient: So he, but actually, the oxycodone are the ones with the numbers there? One or two at the beginning. Because that’s the way he did it. And when I do it, I just put down when I’m taking it. I don’t that, take it that often. I know that, uh, uh, when I got the prescription, they told me to stay in front of the, the pain, so, or else you’re going to have to start from scratch again to get back where you were at. But I was a little leery of taking, uh, uh, uh, drugs that often. Doctor: So it looks like some days you’re taking it twice, like August eighteenth? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then some days, like August twentieth, you didn’t take it at all? Patient: No. Doctor: And twenty-first, you didn’t take it at all, and then the twenty-second, which is today, you took one in the morning? Patient: Yes. And I took one when I got here, too. I didn’t write it down. I took one after I got here because I could feel in my thighs, so I did take one, uh, when we got to the, to, the facility today. Doctor: Do you think the experimental drug is working? The Patient: Oh, I, I know it’s working. I believe it is. Doctor: And what makes you think that it’s working? Patient: I believe it from the perspective of where I was having pain at and not, uh, from a perspective of, uh, uh, uh, uh, since we lowered the doses- Doctor: Um hum. Patient: That I’ve been feeling pretty good for the most part. Uh, just as long as I don’t overexert myself. And that’s one of the biggest things, that, you know, you’re feeling good. And you said, okay, I’m going to do a little extra today, and that may be a no-no. You know? So I, you know, even at my church, I got up and, uh, I think that was two Sundays ago or three Sundays ago, and, uh, I stayed up too long and I preached too hard. And I paid for it the next twenty-four hours of doing it. I should have just cut it short. So what I do now, is like last week, they had church conference meeting. And I came up on Saturday for church conference meeting to let them know I wasn’t coming up for Sunday services and had one of my associates to –

Patient: For what I have. Doctor: …this one, for prostate cancer, is to start with Taxotere or Docetaxel and that would be what you would get. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: One of the things to consider is you know we do have a new hormonal therapy that is being tested and that would be one potential option for you to look into. Patient: Is that a study? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Clinical study? Doctor: Yeah it’s a clinical trial a hormonal agent that has at least three clinically shown promising results. Patient: And that would be here? Doctor: Then it would have to be. Family Member: So that’s different… Doctor: That’s one option.

Patient: Okay, alright. That’s cool. Doctor: So you duke it out with your wife – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - in terms of whether you go or not, that’s on you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You just know, I have to have you be careful. Patient: I know. Doctor: Okay? Patient: I know. Now doc let me ask you this here. Doctor: Yeah. Yes and then I got to run and answer this page. Shoot. Patient: Yeah. Um (pause) Doctor: Mm,hmm. Patient: - okay, for the weakness for being tired.

Patient: Okay. Alright. Family Member: If he has non-cancer issues, he goes to him primary? Patient: Primary doctor, correct? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah, they’re smarter than us. Family Member: If he thinks he has a hernia, would that show on the CT scan? Would that be appropriate to send to the doctor? Doctor: No, because, yeah, the hernia, you know, when you’re laying down it really has to be pretty bad for it to be seen laying down. It’s usually when you’re standing up or sitting that it comes out. A hernia just means you have a weak area of muscle and then you have your bowel spill out. Typically, it doesn’t bother you unless it gets stuck, you know. Patient: Okay. Family Member: He’s having a lot of pain shooting up. Patient: Just I have a problem with my groin Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: I thought you were gonna say too that they weren’t’ playing nice about the the the the (stammers) Family Member: We’ve had a lot of that lately. Patient: That accompanies the injection or the… Doctor: Yes, your Neulasta is whole ‘nother whatever, I know. Patient: Because M___ had made the comment that… Doctor: Yeah another patient… Patient: …you had another patient that his insurance wouldn’t cover it until… Doctor: It’s the same thing. Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: Until you actually have a problem and then they go oh look he’s got a problem, okay we’ll give it to you now. I know. Patient: That’s terrible. Doctor: It’s terrible. So…

Patient: You should have had uh, you should of had something here from where I had three broken ribs from a car wreck which I explained to the guy. You’re gonna see something there… Doctor: Yeah, yeah… Patient: …from a car wreck. Doctor: And it wasn’t even that that prominent. Patient: You’re gonna see stuff there. Doctor: You got that, I saw that, yep. So the good part is it’s, not the good part but, it’s primarily localized right here. So the question is what to do. Now one, I know you’ve asked about well why can’t we just go in and radiate or do some stuff there. Patient: It wasn’t quite that simplistic. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: I understand the, you know I, I, I you know basically I said if I have a mass… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: …that’s to me a target, if I have a target. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: and if I’m at the range with my Glock seventeen…

Patient: Yeah. No. Doctor: Yeah. I noticed that. Patient: I’m sorry, Family Member: No, it’s cool. Patient: Uh, but I don’t, I don’t like that, uh, pardon my French, but I don’t like peeing on anyone’s leg, but the insurance companies are just - mmm- driving me to drink. My daughter turned twenty six, and she’s got that - It took her three weeks to figure it out. Two weeks? To figure it out, and then, she calls and they have no record. (whispers) Patient: She has to talk to other people. Doctor: No swelling or anything? Patient: No. Doctor: Great. Okay. Patient: I have these, I had these little under-the-skin cysts for about ages. (pause4sec) Doctor: Okay, so today, your white count’s normal. You’re, you’re not anemic, and your platelets are normal. Your, uh, electrolytes, your sugar is on the high side at one twenty-one. Uh, did you have breakfast today? Patient: I did.

Patient: Worry. You know? Because that, that’s, that’s bad. Doctor: That’s very bad. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Yes. You don’t want to do that. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Stress can cause a lot of problems with the rest, other parts of the body. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Wait at the desk and enjoy the rest of the year. I’ll see you in the early part of next year. Okay? Patient: Alright. Alright. Thank you, Dr. P___, so much. Doctor: No problem. Alright. Very good.

Patient: I got to talk to the heart doctor now because he has me on the aspirin and the… Family Member: Unless you think… Patient: The tush doctor told me no aspirin. Doctor: Don’t take it until – but that could probably be temporary as long as the bleeding has stopped you know if a few weeks they may be able to go ahead and restart. Family Member: So would we be completely transferring care downtown then? Doctor: For? Family Member: Every visit. Doctor: For some time yes. Family Member: And this would be like at first I know it’s super intensive with tests, but then does it go to once a month or is it always more intensive? Doctor: It does eventually. Yes. Yes after the first six to eight weeks. Family Member: But that’s a few months down the road. Patient: And you’d maintain the care?

Patient: Okay but what I do in the meantime (laughs) Doctor: Well that’s why I was saying that well if there was somebody else with you, I’m concerned that you’re going to take both and it will be too much, it will zonk you out. Okay there’s nobody here with you even to tell for me to tell and the dangerous thing is you have your Ambiens at home. Patient: Right. Doctor: So you very well could make a mistake and take both, take the Ambien and the new sleeping pill. Patient: No I wouldn’t take the Ambien then. I’ll just throw them out. Doctor: You sure? Patient: Yeah I will pull them out. Doctor: You’ll remember to do that?
PAT Yes, yes I will. Okay. Patient: Yes I will. I would so like it now I would take them Ambiens that I got, I will pull them out. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Yeah I’ll dispose, how do we say it, dispose of them. Doctor: Now you’re gonna remember to do that? Patient: Yes I am, yes I am.

Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So if you have one of those gasping things, if it’s your old gasping problem or is it the new drug? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So then we’re going to put you on steroids and stuff like that. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: It can attack your colon so then you can have just profuse, non-stop diarrhea and so that we have to stop as well. It can attack your liver so then you get a hepatitis- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: that’s not uh virus-related but drug related. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: There’s other parts of the body. Any part of your body could get one of these “-itises” —pneumonitis, hepatitis, colitis. So we’re tuned to listen to you and let you, teach you how to tell us right away if there is something going on and then we have to judge fast where we think worried/not worried. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: That’s experimental; we don’t know what the real benefit to someone like you is. We can’t tell you we’re going to make you live longer.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: So what I’ve done you dig, I go to the chiropractor and I let him crack it Doctor: Okay. Patient: and all that. You know what I’m saying? Doctor: Yeah. Patient: That feels good. Doctor: You know that’s not my favorite. Patient: I know. Doctor: I think we talked about the chiropractor and when you have stuff in your back it’s probably not the most stable. Patient: I know, I know. Doctor: However, I think this is enough of a signal that that area in the back tells me that it’s a little bit something more than it was. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: That’s the first. The second part is sort of the rest of you and I know W__ wanted to share that too Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Okay. Yeah. Doctor: So this is ascorbic acid is Vitamin C. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: In this docetaxel. So you could use this as material just even docetaxel. It tells you what the side effects are, how often you need to be. The Vitamin C is the experimental part of it. So this would again be intensive to get it done here, but that’s an option. And so this is the one about the immune inhibitors for ARV7 positive tumors and you have to be on the Enzalutamide. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: And this is going to talk about how often you need to be here, what are the side effects, can we get you know the things like that. So this is homework to read to sort of say, “Hey, I would never consider that. There’s too many things going on, I would never do it. Or you know okay it sounds reasonable. Dr. G___ likes it, you like it.” And then we would have that possibility that once we’ve decided you’re no longer benefiting, we will keep you on the Enzalutamide and then we would sort of build this for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you are no longer benefiting but the idea is that I want to go to chemotherapy on its own or as part of the study vis a vis switching to this. Patient: How long would the chemotherapy? How long would that last? Doctor: Okay, so the chemotherapy, we tend to give ten cycles if it’s benefiting you. They’re given once every three weeks. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or if it’s not benefiting you, we usually know by the third or fourth cycle that your PSA is rising and you don’t tolerate it so we have to make some changes.
